Synthesis of N, N, N’, N’-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine(TMHDA) by the amination of 1,6-hexanediol(HDO) and dimethylamine(DMA) at normal pressure over an outstanding Cu/Ni/Zn catalyst supported on aluminum oxide(γ-Al2O3) was studied in this article. Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3(Cu: Ni: Zn = 28: 7: 12) exhibited excellent catalytic performance, which HDO was almost completely transformed and TMHDA reached 85 % selectivity at 200 °C. The amination of HDO required two hydrogenations and two dehydrogenations, and the selectivity of the amination catalyst depended on the balance of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation. Various characterization (TEM, BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS) demonstrated that the addition of Zn to the Cu/Ni catalyst could reduce the agglomeration of Cu/Ni particles and change the valence distribution of Cu. The Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was a very promising and green method for the synthesis of tertiary diamines through amination of diols. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N,N, N’, N’-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine Catalytic amination 1,6-hexanediol Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalysts Characterization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As important fine chemical intermediates, fatty amines and their derivatives are widely used in dyes, pesticides, pharmaceuticals and other fields, and the catalytic amination of alcohols is one of the most important methods to prepare such compounds [1-4]. Over the past century, the researches on catalytic amination of mono-functional alcohols have achieved remarkable results, and a series of high-efficiency catalysts have been developed for this reaction [5-8]. There is little research on the catalytic amination of diols, mainly because when diols are used as raw materials, the reaction with ammonia (amine) is more complex than that with mono-functional alcohols. It is very easy for diols to occur intramolecular or intermolecular tandem reactions to generate a series of chain or ring products, which reduces the selectivity of the reaction and prevents the production of high-yield compounds [9-13]. Li et al. applied Ru/Al2O3 catalyst to the amination reaction of 1,6-hexanediol. Under the optimal reaction conditions, 1,6-hexanediol was almost completely converted, but the selectivity of 1,6-hexamethylene diamine was only 38.4 % [9]. Therefore, the method of preparing diamine by catalytic amination of diols is rarely used in industry at present, and only part of ethylenediamine is prepared by the catalytic amination of ethanolamine [14]. In industry, most diamines are still synthesized from dihalides and cyanide, which involves a serious corrosion of equipment and a heavy environmental pollution [14,15]. The catalytic amination reaction of diols does not have the above disadvantages, and the rest products of the reaction can be sold as products after separation, with little environmental pollution. At present, the main difficulty lies in the low selectivity of the catalyst towards the target compound. If the problem can be solved, this will be a very promising and green synthesis route. The catalysts used to catalyze the amination reaction of alcohols can be generally divided into two categories: noble metal catalysts and non-noble metal catalysts [16]. Noble metals like Ru [17,18], Pd [19], Ir [20], Pt [21] have been employed in the reaction, which are efficient, stable, selective and generally exhibit excellent catalytic activity. However, the noble metals are relatively scarce and very expensive, which greatly limited the industrial application. In contrast, non-noble metals are abundant on the earth. Over the decades, people have increasingly replaced noble metals with more economical metals [22-30]. The research of non-noble metal catalysts mainly focused Cu [23-26], Ni [27,28] and Co [29,30], etc. Beepala et al. synthesized a series of Cu/SBA-15 catalysts used to synthesize cyclohexylamine from cyclohexanol, which showed the best catalytic performance when loaded with 5 wt% Cu on SBA-15 [24]. Tomer et al. added β-cyclodextrin to the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, showing high conversion and primary amine selectivity in the amination reaction between n-octanol and ammonia [27]. A great deal of studies has shown that doping other metals (Fe [29,31], Zn [25], Bi [32], Ag [33], Re [34], V[35], etc.) into metal catalysts has a significant impact to the activity and selectivity of catalysts in alcohol reduction amination reaction. Cai et al. studied that Zn can enhance the catalytic selectivity of Cu/γ-Al2O3 in the amination process of HDO reduction to N, N, N’, N’-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine (TMHDA), which was due to the strong electron interaction between Zn and Cu nanoparticles to decrease the average particle size and improve the dispersion of Cu [25]. In addition, the valence of the active component also affects the selectivity of the catalyst in the amination reaction. Abe et al. found some differences in the valence states of Ni in catalysts with different Cu/Ni ratios on the reduction of fatty alcohols to tertiary amines. The higher the Cu/Ni ratio, the more biased its valence state to Ni3+, the higher the selectivity [6,36]. Li et al. reported that the catalyst selectivity was affected by the reducibility of Ni2+, and lower Ni2+ reducibility resulted in higher catalyst selectivity [37]. Actually, the majority of studies focus on the preparation of primary diamines and secondary diamines by catalytic amination, and there are only few researches on the preparation of tertiary diamines directly from the reductive amination of diols. Tetramethyl diamines (Me2N-(CH2)n-NMe2) are an important organic synthesis intermediate in the industrial production of polyurethane [38], multiheaded cationic surfactants [39] and anion exchange membranes [40,41]. Runeberg et al. reported that the main product of the vapor amination reaction between ethylene glycol and DMA was 2-dimethylaminoethanol, and the selectivity of tetramethyl diamine was less than 20 % [42]. BASF patented the amination reaction of diols with DMA under pressure on a Cu/Cr catalyst, with the conversion rate was 15 % and the selectivity of the intermediate and tertiary diamines was 30 % and 20 %, respectively [43]. Hence, it is meaningful to develop efficient synthesis of tetramethyl diamines. Herein, we prepared a battery of Cu/Ni/Zn catalysts with different supports, different components and different proportions by co-precipitation method, and the catalytic performance for HDO and DMA catalytic synthesis to TMHDA was evaluated. Compared to previous studies, in this research, non-noble metallic elements such as Cu, Ni and Zn are used, which have low cost and can be reused many times. The HDO conversion and goal product TMHDA have been greatly improved. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism of tertiary diamine by amination of diols was also explored. The catalyst structure (dispersion, electron interaction, reduction degree, etc.) was investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments, X-ray diffraction (XRD), hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), etc. The results showed that smaller Cu and Ni particles and suitable Cu+ and Cu0 mixture facilitated the formation of TMHDA. The Cu/Ni/Zn catalysts for synthesis of TMHDA is of a great potential application as a green and effective route to produce tertiary diamine. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials 1,6-Hexanediol (99.1 %, A.R.) was obtained from Shanghai Haohong Scientific Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. Dimethylamine with a purity of >99.5 % was purchased from Zibo Huibao Chemical Co., Ltd., Shandong, China. High purity H2 with a purity of >99.99 % was provided by Taiyuan Taineng Gas Co., Ltd., Taiyuan, China. Cu(NO3)2•3H2O (98.5 %, A.R.), Ni(NO3)2•6H2O (98.0 %, A.R.), Zn(NO3)2•6H2O (99.0 %, A.R.), and Na2CO3 (99.0 %, A.R.) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. Pseudo boehmite (AlOOH· nH2O, n = 0.08∼0.62, Nitric acid preparation, A.R.), light calcium carbonate and diatomite were supplied by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. All experiments used the Millipore water with 18.2 MΩ•cm. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method. A calculated amount of pseudo boehmite and deionized water were prepared 10 wt.% solution. A calculated amount of Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, Zn(NO3)2•6H2O were also dissolved in deionized water to prepare solution. Then the solutions of Cu/Ni/Zn nitrates and Na2CO3 were added dropwise to the above pseudo boehmite solution under 45 °C with the solution pH around 7∼8. After there was no Cu/Ni/Zn nitrates solution left, the mixture was kept stirring for 2 h with the stirring speed around 300 rpm. The filter cake was filtrated and washed until the pH dropped to weakly alkalescent. Finally, the filter cake was dried at 120 °C for 6 h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 3 h. Before used, the prepared catalyst was crushed into 200 mesh. The other two CaCO3 and diatomite supported catalysts were also prepared by the above method. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic reaction was carried out in a round bottom flask and a reflux condenser with a triangular flask was used to collect the reaction water. In order to collect as much the reaction water as possible while minimizing volatilization of the other reactants and products, the condensate tube was filled with stainless steel θ ring helices and the temperature of the condensate water was set at 50 °C. 1,6-hexanediol and catalyst were put into the flask. The catalyst was reduced in H2 flow (0.8 L/min) at 170 °C for 40 min. Then the mixture of dimethylamine (DMA, 60 vol %, 0.6 L/min) and H2 (40 vol %, 0.4 L/min) was fed into the reactor. The liquid mixtures for analysis were taken at 4 h, 6 h, 8 h of reaction at 200 °C. The liquid mixtures from the amination reaction were analyzed by a gas chromatography (GC8860A, Agilent) with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column (HP-5 column). The conversion of HDO and selectivity of TMHDA were calculated according to the formula below: Conversion (%) =(C0-Ct)/C0, C0, Ct represent the initial concentration and the concentration at time t of HDO, respectively. Yield (%) =Cpt/Cp0, Cpt, Cp0 represent the concentration at time t and theoretical concentration of TMHDA, respectively. Selectivity (%) = Yield/Conversion. 2.4 Characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was collected on a FEI-Talos F200S with a 200-kV electron source. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a HITACHI SU8010 with an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were determined via a German Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source in a 2θ range from 10° to 80° Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was tested in a flow of 10 vol% H2/Ar (25 mL/min) on a Microtrac BelCata II instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha. The C1s peak at 284.8 eV was used as a reference for charge–up correction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 composite Four catalysts with different Cu, Ni and Zn contents were prepared by the method mentioned in 2.2. Cu/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3 were single-element catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3. Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 contained Cu and Ni two elements, which the molar ratio of Cu and Ni was 4:1. Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 contained Cu, Ni and Zn three elements, which the molar ratio of Cu, Ni and Zn was 28:7:12. Different characterization was carried out for the four catalysts. TEM images of Cu/γ-Al2O3, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3, Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 were shown in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1, the particle agglomeration of Cu/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1A) and Ni/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1B) containing was quite serious. When Ni and Cu were loaded on the carrier at the same time, Ni can be well dispersed between Cu particles, which was the basis for the excellent catalytic properties of Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1C). After adding Zn, the average size of catalyst decreased from 21.382 nm to 15.648 nm, which indicated that Zn can reduce the agglomeration of Cu, thus promote the homogeneous distribution of Cu particles (Fig. 1D) [44]. The EDS elemental mapping of Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 in SEM images (Fig.S1) displayed the uniform dispersion of Cu, Ni, Zn elements on Al2O3 support, implying that there might be good interaction among Cu, Ni and Zn in Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3. The specific surface area (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method) and pore distribution of four catalysts were performed. All N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 2 A) showed a typical Type IV model with H3-type hysteresis loops [45]. The H3-type hysteresis loop showed no adsorption saturation in the region of higher relative pressure, which indicated Al2O3 was suitable for the support of the amination catalyst. In Fig. 2B, all samples exhibited a unimodal distribution and the pore width distributed at about 3∼4 nm, indicating that the pore size distribution of four catalysts were relatively uniform. In Table S1, Cu/γ-Al2O3 (212.9 m2/g) had a larger surface area than Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 (188.1 m2/g) and Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3(184.1 m2/g). Meanwhile, the pore volumes exhibited the same tendency, which decreased from 0.311 to 0.275 cm3/g and 0.267 cm3/g. This phenomenon suggested that Ni and Zn may be deposited in pores [25]. The XRD patterns were also performed to record the crystallinity of the four catalysts after calcination and reduction in Fig. 3 A and B, respectively. In Fig. 3A, two strong peaks of Cu/γ-Al2O3(a) appeared at 35.5° and 38.7°, corresponding to the (002) and (111) planes of the diffraction peak of CuO (PDF No 45–0937), indicating that CuO existed as relatively large particles. When Ni and Cu were combined(c), the peak of CuO becomed broader and weaker. It indicated that the higher dispersion of Cu in Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3. With the addition of Zn, the diffraction peak appeared at 36.3°, corresponding to (101) plane of ZnO (PDF No 80–0047). Fig. 3B was XRD patterns of the catalysts after reduction. The diffraction peak of CuO was disappeared in Cu/γ-Al2O3(a), Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 (c), Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 (d), but the common diffraction peaks of 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1° were assigned to the (111) (200) and (220) facets of metal Cu (PDF No 99–0034), respectively. This confirmed that CuO was reduced to Cu. In addition, the Cu diffraction peaks of Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 (d) were significantly weaker than that of Cu/γ-Al2O3 (a), indicating that existed a better dispersion of Cu particles in Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3. Furthermore, the crystal size of both calcined and reduced materials from the XRD diffractograms were estimated calculated by Debye-Scherrer equation (Table S1), which the trend was similar to the average size of TEM. H2-TPR of the four catalysts (Cu/γ-Al2O3, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3, Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3) were performed to investigate the reduction behavior, and the results were shown in Fig. 4 . The reduction temperature of Ni/γ-Al2O3 (b) was 302 ℃, corresponding to the Ni2+ to Ni0 reduction process in the catalyst. The reduction temperature of Cu/γ-Al2O3 (a) was 197 ℃, corresponding to the reduction process of Cu2+ to Cu0. These results showed that the reduction of Ni2+ was much more difficult than that of Cu2+. For the Cu reduction center, with the addition of Ni and Zn in turn(c and d), the hydrogen consumption peak of CuO shifted to lower temperature, and the reduction temperature decreased to 194 ℃, 190 ℃, respectively. For the Ni reduction center, the reduction temperature of NiO decreased significantly after adding Cu and Zn. The decline of reduction temperature could be ascribed to a strong synergism among Cu, Ni and Zn [46]. The hydrogen consumption of Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 was less than that of Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3. This could be attributed to the non-reduction of the added ZnO. Since the standard reduction potential of Zn2+(E0 = −0.763) was lower than that of Ni2+(E0 = −0.246) and Cu2+(E0 = 0.337), it was difficult to reduce ZnO with H2 under the TPR conditions. In order to observe the chemical states and electronic structures of four catalysts, XPS measurements were carried out. In Fig. S2 and S3, the full XPS spectra of four catalysts after calcination (Fig. S2) and after reduction (Fig. S3) contained the corresponding C, O, Cu, Ni, Zn and Al elements. The excrescent Na could be attributed to residual Na2CO3 on the catalysts. In the catalysts, the strongest energy absorption of Cu and Ni were the absorption of 2p electrons. Therefore, XPS spectra after deconvolution and binding energy of Cu 2p and Ni 2p of four catalysts after calcination were shown in Fig. S4 and Table S2, respectively. Cu 2p in a, c, d catalysts and Ni 2p in b, c, d catalysts after calcination both showed obvious Cu2+ characteristics (strong satellites) and Ni2+ characteristics (multiplet-split Ni 2p3/2). In Fig. S5, after calcination and after reduction, the binding energy and the peak intensity of Zn 2p were basically unchanged, indicating ZnO had not been reduced, which was in accord with the results of TPR. The XPS spectra of Cu 2p and Ni 2p in Fig. 5 A and B were subjected to peak fitting processing. For Cu 2p of catalysts after reduction, we could confirm the valence state of Cu was Cu0/Cu+. Firstly, the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 in a, c, d catalysts (Table S3) were close to the binding energy of Cu metal (932.6 eV) and Cu (I) oxide (932.7 eV) instead of Cu (II) oxide (933.1 eV). Secondly, all three Cu 2p XPS spectra of a, c, d catalysts had weak satellites, which was accordant with Cu metal (no satellites) and Cu (I) oxide (weak satellites) instead of Cu (II) oxide (strong satellites). To further distinguish Cu0 and Cu+, the Cu LMM Auger were also tested and the peaks belonging to Cu+ and Cu0 were obtained by peak separation processing (Fig. S6). It was worth noting that the Cu° contents increased with adding Ni and Zn (Table S3). Wang et al. believed that both Cu0 and Cu+ have catalytic effects in hydrogenation reaction and these two active Cu sites on enhancing the catalytic performance play different roles [47,48]. For Ni 2p of catalysts after reduction, we could confirm the valence state of Ni was Ni2+. Firstly, the binding energy of Ni 2p3/2 in b, c, d catalysts (Table S3) were close to the binding energy of NiO (853.7 eV) instead of Ni metal (852.6 eV). Secondly, all three Ni 2p XPS spectra of b, c, d catalysts had multiplet-split Ni 2p3/2 and strong satellites, which was accordant with NiO instead of Ni metal (no multiplet-split Ni 2p3/2 and weak satellites). On one hand, the valence state of Cu and Ni were Cu2+ and Ni2+ after calcination while the valence state of Cu and Ni were Cu0/Cu+ and Ni2+ after reduction, indicating that Cu2+ was easier to reduce than Ni2+, which was also confirmed by XRD and H2-TPR. On the other hand, a certain proportion of Cu0 and Cu+ could promote the activity and selectivity of the catalyst achieve the best effect. The catalysts composition of four catalysts after reduction were characterized by ICP-OES. The ICP-OES analysis data were added to Table S1. ICP-OES results indicated the contents of Cu, Ni and Zn were slightly less than default values, but the overall differences were not much. 3.2 Catalytic performance In order to investigate the catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts, the amination experiments of HDO and DMA were carried out according to method 2.3. The relationship between HDO conversion and TMHDA selectivity and reaction time for four catalysts was in Fig. 6 . For Cu/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3, the TMHDA contents at 8 h were 3.6 % and 4.9 %, while for Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3, the TMHDA contents at 8 h reached about 65.9 % and 85.6 %, respectively. Catalytic performances of other three catalysts (Cu/Zn/γ-Al2O3, Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3, Zn/γ-Al2O3) were evaluated for further investigating the catalytic performance of Cu, Ni and Zn (Fig. S7). The TMHDA selectivity of Cu/Zn/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 did not reach 20 % after 8 h. What's more, the yield of TMHDA was only about 1 % over Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. All catalytic results of seven catalysts indicated that coexistence of Cu and Ni was essential in the amination catalyst for the synthesis of TMHDA by catalyzed amination of HDO and DMA [46]. The results demonstrated the strong interaction between Cu, Ni and Zn on the surface of Al2O3 was the critical role in the improvement of catalytic activity. In essence, the formation process of TMHDA requires two hydrogenations and two dehydrogenations (Scheme 1 ) [25,49]. On one hand, it requires the catalyst possesses the capability of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation at the same time. In Cu/Ni-based supported amination catalysts, copper mainly played a dehydrogenation role while nickel mainly played a hydrogenation role, and copper and nickel must be contained to make the catalyst have dehydrogenation and hydrogenation at the same time [50]. On the other hand, the selectivity of the amination catalyst depended on the balance of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation, which required the catalyst structure and reaction conditions to be appropriate [36]. Therefore, the catalyst support, component ratio, reaction temperature and reaction time were further studied. The most widely used catalyst in catalytic amination is the supported catalyst. On one hand, the support can prevent the evolution of copper and improve the stability of the catalyst. On the other hand, adding the support can reduce the cost, which has economic significance. The commonly used catalyst supports include alumina, silica gel, activated carbon, diatomaceous earth, calcium carbonate and so on [51]. In order to obtain the catalyst with better performance, three different catalyst supports were studied. According to the method mentioned in 2.2, catalysts with CaCO3, diatomaceous earth and γ-Al2O3 as supports were prepared respectively, and then amination experiments were performed. The experimental results were in Fig. 7 A. As shown in Fig. 7A, compared with CaCO3 and diatomite, γ-Al2O3 as the catalyst support had relatively superior performance, which the TMHDA content was much higher than that of the other two supports. BET tests were conducted on three different supported catalysts to study the physicochemical properties of catalyst samples. The results were shown in Table S4, Fig. 7B and C. As shown in Table S4, the surface area and pore volume of the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst were much larger than those of the other two supported catalysts, indicating that the Cu and Ni were well dispersed on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface, which was favorable for amination reaction. The N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves were shown in Fig. 7B and C. The γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst had a typical type IV isotherm with a H3-type hysteresis loop, indicating that the holes of γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst were uniform size and regular shape. The CaCO3 and diatomite supported catalysts showed characteristic III isotherms with H4-type hysteresis loops. The BET surface areas and pore volumes of the two supported catalysts were both very small, which indicated the two catalyst support were almost solid particles and few channels existed. The pore size distribution of the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst are unimodal and narrow, so the pore size distribution was more uniform. The influence of reaction temperature on the TMHDA selectivity was explored, as shown in Fig. S8. At 180 ℃, the TMHDA content was relatively low, while the content of intermediate product DMAHO (6-dimethylamino-1-hexanol) was high. With the rise of temperature, DMAHO continued to transform into TMHDA. The reason was that the preparation of diamine catalyzed by diol was a dehydration reaction, which required two dehydrations to obtain the target product TMHDA. Under higher temperature, the water removed from the dehydration reaction can be taken away thus the reaction can continue to proceed. Therefore, 200 ℃ was a more appropriate reaction temperature for the amination reaction of HDO and DMA to TMHDA. Then, five different Cu/Ni molar ratios catalysts (n(Cu)/n(Ni) = 5:1, 4:1, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1) using γ-Al2O3 as supports were prepared, and then amination experiments were conducted. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 8 A, B and C. When the reaction time was 4 h (Fig. 8A), all TMHDA contents were relatively low while the intermediate product DMAHO contents were higher. As reaction time extended to 6 h (Fig. 8B), TMHDA contents were on the rise. For the 4:1 Cu/Ni catalyst, the reaction results reached a high level at 8 h, which the selectivity of TMHDA reached 69 % with only 2 % DMAHO remaining (Fig. 8C). It confirmed that the Cu-Ni ratio should be appropriate, and excess Cu or Ni were unfavorable to the experimental process, which was consistent with the view that the selectivity of the amination catalyst depends on the balance of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation [36]. In view of the good performance of Zn in amination catalysts, four different Cu/Ni/Zn molar ratios catalysts (n(Cu)/n(Ni)/n(Zn)= 28:7:6, 28:7:12, 28:7:20, 28:7:28) were prepared, and then amination experiments were conducted [25,48]. The experimental results were shown in Fig. 8D, E and F. On the basis of the optimized Cu/Ni catalyst, the selectivity of TMHDA could be greatly improved by adding the third component Zn. Compared with the 4:1 Cu/Ni catalyst of 69 %, the Cu/Ni/Zn catalyst (n(Cu)/n(Ni)/n(Zn) = 28:7:12) had a higher TMHDA selectivity of 85 %. Hence, the introduction of Zn was effective for the Cu/Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst to enhance the catalytic capability. 3.3 Catalytic reusability The reusability of Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (n(Cu)/n(Ni)/n(Zn)=28:7:12) was evaluated (Fig. 9 ). Before used in next cycle, the catalyst was washed with ethanol and deionized water three times and dry in vacuum oven 60 ℃ for 12 h. Besides 5 % new catalyst was added for replenishing the loss. The Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst could keep the content of TMHDA above 85 % during the first four cycles. In fifth cycle, the yield of TMHDA had been reduced to 75 %, which the sintering of Cu and Ni particles leading the increase of average particle size should be the reason for the decrease of catalytic activity according to the TEM images Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst after the fifth cycle (Fig. S9) [10]. 4 Conclusion and perspective We developed a series of Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalysts by co-precipitation, which was used for HDO and DMA catalytic synthesis to TMHDA, and the structure-activity relationship was studied. The formation process of TMHDA required two hydrogenations and two dehydrogenations. The selectivity of catalysts depended on the balance of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation. The gain effect of Zn on the Cu/Ni dehydrogenation-hydrogenation catalyst can be attributed to two aspects. On one hand, there was a strong synergistic effect among Cu, Ni and Zn, which was conducive to the dispersion of Cu, Ni particles and the generation of more active sites. On the other hand, Zn had an effect on the valence states of Cu after reduction, and a certain proportion of Cu+ and Cu0 would produce a synergistic effect, thus improving the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. In this work, an optimized effective Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was used to synthesis tetramethylenediamine, and a promising idea was supplied for industrial production of tertiary diamine by amination of diols on non-noble metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis of N, N, N’, N’-tetramethyl-1,6-hexanediamine(TMHDA) by the amination of 1,6-hexanediol(HDO) and dimethylamine(DMA) at normal pressure over an outstanding Cu/Ni/Zn catalyst supported on aluminum oxide(γ-Al2O3) was studied in this article. Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3(Cu: Ni: Zn = 28: 7: 12) exhibited excellent catalytic performance, which HDO was almost completely transformed and TMHDA reached 85 % selectivity at 200 °C. The amination of HDO required two hydrogenations and two dehydrogenations, and the selectivity of the amination catalyst depended on the balance of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation. Various characterization (TEM, BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS) demonstrated that the addition of Zn to the Cu/Ni catalyst could reduce the agglomeration of Cu/Ni particles and change the valence distribution of Cu. The Cu/Ni/Zn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was a very promising and green method for the synthesis of tertiary diamines through amination of diols.
